title: Can you guess what's wrong with these paintings? - Noah Charney

options.label: B
options.text: That it was from a different era.

options.label: C
options.text: That it was a modern fake.

options.text: Past restorers took a minimal intervention approach, while today's restorers take a more heavy-handed approach.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Past restorers focused on preserving the original work, while today's restorers focus on improving the art.

options.label: D
options.text: Past restorers used varnish to protect paintings, while today's restorers do not.

multiple-choice.question: What was used to protect paintings from debris and make their colors pop, but eventually darkened and gave older paintings a yellowy look?

options.label: A
options.text: The portrait was restored to its original state, and it was done to preserve its historical significance.

options.label: B
options.text: The portrait was altered to make Isabella appear more attractive, and it was done to boost sales.

options.label: C
options.text: The portrait was damaged, and it was done accidentally.

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: The painting was altered to make it more risqué.

options.label: C
options.text: The painting was censored to obscure Venus's tongue and nipple.

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: To preserve the art in its original state and prevent further damage.

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: They use a conductive substance to complete an electric circuit when something pushes hard enough.

options.label: B
options.text: They use a capacitive substance to complete an electric circuit when something pushes hard enough.

options.label: C
options.text: They use an insulating substance to complete an electric circuit when something pushes hard enough.

options.label: D
options.text: They use a conductive substance to break an electric circuit when something pushes hard enough.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between resistive and capacitive touchscreens?

options.label: A
options.text: Resistive touchscreens are more expensive, while capacitive touchscreens are cheaper.

options.label: B
options.text: Resistive touchscreens require force to activate, while capacitive touchscreens do not.

options.label: C
options.text: Resistive touchscreens are more durable, while capacitive touchscreens are less durable.

options.label: D
options.text: Resistive touchscreens are less responsive, while capacitive touchscreens are more responsive.

multiple-choice.question: Why do capacitive touchscreens work well with human fingers?

options.label: C
options.text: Because human fingers are made of a special material that interacts with touchscreens.

options.label: D
options.text: Because human fingers are always dry.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when you try to use a smartphone while your hands are wet or gloved?

options.label: C
options.text: The electrical connection between your finger and phone is interrupted.

options.label: D
options.text: The phone's battery runs out quickly.

multiple-choice.question: Why do objects like banana peels and certain processed meats activate capacitive touchscreens?

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are made of a special material that interacts with touchscreens.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the nodes in a capacitive touchscreen?

options.label: A
options.text: To store charge and act like capacitors.

options.label: B
options.text: To conduct electricity and act like wires.

options.label: C
options.text: To insulate electricity and act like barriers.

options.label: D
options.text: To produce images and act like LCD screens.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when water is splashed across a capacitive touchscreen?

options.label: C
options.text: The electrical connection between your finger and phone is interrupted.

options.label: D
options.text: The phone could act like you've touched it in multiple places at once.

multiple-choice.question: What is the standout strength of hagfish?

title: What’s the best country to live in?

options.label: B
options.text: The total GDP divided by the number of people living in that country

options.label: C

title: What happens to your body at the top of Mount Everest - Andrew Lovering

multiple-choice.question: What would happen to someone who teleported from sea level to the top of Mt. Everest?

options.label: A
options.text: They would experience a sudden increase in oxygen levels.

options.label: B
options.text: They would likely suffocate in minutes due to low oxygen levels.

options.label: C
options.text: They would experience no change in oxygen levels.

options.label: D
options.text: They would experience a sudden decrease in blood pressure.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary cause of altitude sickness (AMS) when ascending to high altitudes?

options.label: C
options.text: Ascending too quickly, resulting in oxygen deprivation.

multiple-choice.question: What is the immediate response of the body to high altitudes (above 1,500 meters)?

options.label: A
options.text: Decreased heart rate and breathing rate.

options.label: B
options.text: Increased heart rate and breathing rate to counteract low oxygen levels.

options.label: C
options.text: No change in heart rate and breathing rate.

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of staying at high altitudes (above 1,500 meters) for several weeks?

options.label: B
options.text: Increased plasma volume in the blood.

options.label: C
options.text: Increased hemoglobin levels, allowing for more efficient oxygen distribution.

multiple-choice.question: What is ventilatory acclimatization, and when does it occur?

options.label: A
options.text: A decrease in breathing rate, occurring immediately at high altitudes.

options.label: B
options.text: An increase in breathing rate, occurring over several weeks at high altitudes.

options.label: C
options.text: A decrease in heart rate, occurring immediately at high altitudes.

options.label: D
options.text: An increase in blood pressure, occurring over several weeks at high altitudes.

multiple-choice.question: What are the risks associated with ascending to extremely high altitudes (above 3,500 meters)?

options.label: B
options.text: Increased risk of HACE and HAPE, conditions that can be life-threatening.

options.label: C
options.text: No change in risk of altitude sickness.

multiple-choice.question: What genetic advantage do some Tibetans and South Americans have?

options.label: A
options.text: Immunity to all forms of altitude sickness.

options.label: C
options.text: Genetic advantages that can prevent minor altitude sickness.

multiple-choice.question: What is HACE, and what are its effects on the body?

options.label: A
options.text: High Altitude Cerebral Edema, causing fluid buildup in the brain.

options.label: B
options.text: High Altitude Pulmonary Edema, causing fluid buildup in the lungs.

options.label: C
options.text: High Altitude Cardiac Edema, causing fluid buildup in the heart.

options.label: D
options.text: High Altitude Muscular Edema, causing fluid buildup in the muscles.

multiple-choice.question: What is HAPE, and what are its effects on the body?

options.label: A
options.text: High Altitude Pulmonary Edema, causing fluid buildup in the lungs.

options.label: B
options.text: High Altitude Cerebral Edema, causing fluid buildup in the brain.

options.label: C
options.text: High Altitude Cardiac Edema, causing fluid buildup in the heart.

options.label: D
options.text: High Altitude Muscular Edema, causing fluid buildup in the muscles.

multiple-choice.question: What have climbers over the last century proved about human adaptation to high altitudes?

options.label: A
options.text: That humans cannot adapt to high altitudes.

options.label: B
options.text: That humans can only adapt to moderate altitudes.

options.label: C
options.text: That humans can adapt to extremely high altitudes, pushing past their body's limitations.

options.label: D
options.text: That humans can only adapt to high altitudes with genetic advantages.

title: The British Museum is full of stolen artifacts

multiple-choice.question: What is the British Museum, and what makes it significant?

options.label: A
options.text: It is the world's largest art museum, holding over 1 million cultural and historical artifacts.

options.label: B
options.text: It is the world's largest world history museum, holding over 8 million cultural and historical artifacts.

options.label: C
options.text: It is the world's oldest museum, holding over 5 million cultural and historical artifacts.

options.label: D
options.text: It is the world's smallest museum, holding over 100,000 cultural and historical artifacts.

options.label: A
options.text: They are too old and fragile to be displayed.

options.label: B
options.text: They were acquired illegally and have disputed ownership.

options.label: C
options.text: They are too valuable to be displayed in public.

options.label: D
options.text: They are not relevant to the museum's collection.

options.label: A
options.text: They were gifted to the museum by the Kingdom of Benin.

options.label: B
options.text: They were purchased by the museum from a collector.

options.label: C
options.text: They were taken by British troops during the Benin Punitive Expedition in 1897.

options.label: D
options.text: They were found in an archaeological excavation.

multiple-choice.question: Why are the Benin Bronzes significant to the people of Nigeria?

options.label: A
options.text: They are valuable artifacts that can be sold for a high price.

options.label: B
options.text: They are a part of their cultural and historical identity.

options.label: C
options.text: They are a symbol of their colonial past.

options.label: D
options.text: They are a reminder of their independence.

multiple-choice.question: What is the British Museum's stance on returning disputed artifacts?

options.label: A
options.text: They are committed to returning all disputed artifacts to their rightful owners.

options.label: B
options.text: They are restricted by a government act that prevents them from returning objects.

options.label: C
options.text: They are willing to lend artifacts to other museums and institutions.

options.label: D
options.text: They do not have a clear stance on the issue.

multiple-choice.question: What is the Benin Dialogue Group, and what is its purpose?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a group of collectors who are interested in purchasing the Benin Bronzes.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a group of museum curators who are discussing the return of the Benin Bronzes.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a group of Nigerian government representatives and Western museums that are discussing potential solutions for the return of the Benin Bronzes.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a group of historians who are researching the history of the Benin Bronzes.

multiple-choice.question: Why is the issue of disputed artifacts in museums a complex one?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a simple issue of returning stolen artifacts to their rightful owners.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a complex issue that involves cultural and historical identity, colonial power, and the ownership of artifacts.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a financial issue that involves the value of the artifacts.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a logistical issue that involves the transportation of artifacts.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the Rosetta Stone in the British Museum?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a disputed artifact that was taken by British troops from Egypt.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a valuable artifact that was purchased by the museum from a collector.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a symbol of the museum's collection of Egyptian artifacts.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a reminder of the museum's colonial past.

multiple-choice.question: What is the Parthenon Sculptures, and why are they significant?

options.label: A
options.text: They are a collection of sculptures that were gifted to the British Museum by the Greek government.

options.label: B
options.text: They are a collection of sculptures that were taken by British Lord Elgin from the Acropolis in Athens.

options.label: C
options.text: They are a symbol of the museum's collection of Greek artifacts.

options.label: D
options.text: They are a reminder of the museum's colonial past.

multiple-choice.question: What is the ultimate goal of the efforts to return disputed artifacts to their rightful owners?

options.label: A
options.text: To return all disputed artifacts to their rightful owners.

options.label: B
options.text: To create a new museum that showcases the artifacts in a more culturally sensitive way.

options.label: C
options.text: To provide financial compensation to the communities from which the artifacts were taken.

options.label: D
options.text: To start a process of cultural reconstitution and reconciliation.

title: Why can parrots talk? - Grace Smith-Vidaurre and Tim Wright

multiple-choice.question: What unique ability do parrots and several other birds possess?

options.label: A
options.text: They can fly faster than other birds.

options.label: C
options.text: They can mimic other animals' sounds.

options.label: D
options.text: They can see in the dark.

multiple-choice.question: Why do parrots use contact calls?

options.label: B
options.text: To interact and stay in touch with other parrots when they are out of sight.

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the syrinx of parrots compared to other birds?

options.label: C
options.text: It is located at the top of the windpipe.

options.label: D
options.text: It is only found in songbirds.

multiple-choice.question: How do parrots shape sounds into enunciated words?

options.label: D
options.text: Using their beak and jaw joints.

multiple-choice.question: What is special about the tongues of parrots?

options.label: B
options.text: They are especially flexible and powerful.

options.label: C
options.text: They are only used for eating.

options.label: D
options.text: They are only used for speaking.

multiple-choice.question: What do scientists think is the purpose of the additional circuit in parrots' brains?

options.label: A
options.text: To help them learn the calls of their own species.

options.label: B
options.text: To help them learn the calls of other species.

options.label: C
options.text: To help them remember complex sounds.

options.label: D
options.text: To help them produce complex sounds.

multiple-choice.question: Why do captive parrots talk?

options.label: A
options.text: To form social bonds with their owners.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a parrot understanding the meaning of a word?

options.label: A
options.text: Saying "goodnight" at the beginning of the day.

options.label: B
options.text: Saying "goodnight" at the end of the day.

options.label: C
options.text: Asking for a treat and then refusing it.

multiple-choice.question: What is a major threat to wild parrot populations?
Why is it important to study parrots in the wild?

options.label: A
options.text: To understand their behavior in captivity.

options.label: B
options.text: To learn how to train them.

options.label: C
options.text: To preserve and protect their populations.
